docs.lead_paragraph: In the wake of the death of a Red Sox fan hit by a police pepper-spray weapon after the team's playoff victory, Boston officials are imposing restrictions on the bars around Fenway Park and are considering discontinuing use of the pepper-spray gun. The Red Sox' historic victory over the Yankees Wednesday night sent as many as 80,000 people streaming out of bars and homes into the streets around Fenway Park after midnight, many of whom climbed on cars and lampposts and swung from trees.
docs.snippet: Boston officials are imposing restrictions on the bars around Fenway Park to curb violence during the World Series....

headline.main: Death of a Red Sox Fan Leads to Stricter Rules

byline.original: By PAM BELLUCK and KATIE ZEZIMA

docs.lead_paragraph: David Ortiz's toothy, broad smile dominates the imposing billboard just outside the main gates of Fenway Park, imploring Red Sox fans to hang in there. ''Keep the Faith,'' says the billboard, perhaps suggesting that with a player like Ortiz, anything is possible, even in a city that has not won a World Series since 1918. In this instance, no one can accuse the Red Sox of false advertising. Ortiz blossomed when he joined the Red Sox last season as a free agent, puncturing the Yankees in head-to-head games and posting overall numbers -- .288 batting average, 31 home runs and 101 runs batted in -- that led to a fifth-place finish in the American League's most valuable player voting.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox player David Ortiz has 19 home runs and .304 batting average and leads American League in RBI; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I am sitting at my word processor quietly processing my morning quota of words when a loud and raspy string of expletives undeleted shatters my creative cocoon. ''HOWARD! Where did you buy this cheap micro in your kitchen? I pushed every damn button on it trying to heat up my coffee. The damn thing don't work! Throw it out and buy a new one!'' is the version fit for a family newspaper.
docs.abstract: Howard Eisenberg BackTalk column discusses rollercoaster life of former Boston Red Sox lefthanded pitching phenom Mickey McDermott, who spiraled downward into anonymity when drinking took over as his passion; McDermott quit drinking when he won $7 million in lottery, and is now subject of memoir; photos (M)

headline.main: BackTalk; No Quieting Ex-Phenom With Wild Tales On and Off Field

docs.lead_paragraph: A couple of Saturdays ago, in a borrowed office at Fenway Park, Bill James realized what all his writing, theorizing, number crunching and head scratching were about. For six hours, Theo Epstein briefed James on potential trades and free-agent signings the Boston Red Sox could make this winter. James, baseball's ultimate outsider for 25 years, was suddenly very much on the inside. And he loved it. ''I really had a feeling like this is what I've always been preparing to do,'' James said, reflecting on that meeting last week. ''This is what I should be doing.''
docs.abstract: Baseball writer Bill James, author of popular stats series and newly appointed senior adviser to Boston Red Sox, will lend insight to franchise that has not won World Series since 1918; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pedro Martínez, Boston's All-Star pitcher, indicated before yesterday's game at Yankee Stadium that his arm was not sound. ''I don't feel right,'' Martínez said. ''I don't feel good enough to pitch.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Nomar Garciaparra had taken 20 minutes of intense fielding practice, darting to his left or right, flipping throws to second and pumping throws across to first base, before stopping and then standing motionless at shortstop on Wednesday. Now he was waiting for one of the Red Sox to arbitrarily slap a few more grounders toward him. For about a minute, nothing was hit to Garciaparra. He became antsy and kicked at the dirt. Eventually, a ball trickled to him. He scooped it up and kept it. Garciaparra bounced the ball off the outside of his glove and then opened his glove to snare it before it had traveled six inches in the air, almost as if his glove were a wooden paddle and the ball was attached to it by a string. Garciaparra did this over and over to test himself and amuse himself.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox shortstop and premier hitter Nomar Garciaparra returns from disabled list; photo (M)

headline.main: Reason to Believe: Garciaparra Is Back

docs.lead_paragraph: Pedro Martinez won five fewer games this season than he did in 1999, he had fewer strikeouts, allowed more home runs and the Boston Red Sox did not make the playoffs. But Martinez was so much better than any other American League pitcher that he won the Cy Young award unanimously yesterday -- becoming the first to do so in consecutive years. ''I'm really honored and flattered to be chosen unanimously as the winner,'' Martinez said, speaking on a conference call from Boston. ''It is equally special and equally important to last year.''
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox pitcher Pedro Martinez wins American League Cy Young award unanimously, becoming first player to do so in consecutive years; photo (M)

headline.main: No Surprise, Martinez Gets Cy Young Award

docs.lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Dooley, who watched more than 4,000 consecutive Boston Red Sox home games over 55 seasons from her front-row box seat, died Monday in Boston, hours before her beloved Red Sox suffered a 22-1 beating from the Yankees. She was 87, a year younger than Fenway Park, the home of the Red Sox. In 1996, Ted Williams, the greatest Red Sox player of them all, said of Ms. Dooley: ''Forever, she's the greatest Red Sox fan there'll ever be. Every time I get a chance to get around here I like to do it, because she's really a big league gal.''
docs.abstract: Elizabeth Dooley, who watched more than 4,000 consecutive Boston Red Sox home games over 55 seasons from her front-row box seat, dies at age 87; photo (M)
